newsitem.title: GERMANY: Germany gets Peruvian assurance on hostages.
newsitem.headline: Germany gets Peruvian assurance on hostages.

text.p: A Peruvian government official assured German Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel in a telephone call on Wednesday that Peru would do everything in its power to peacefully resolve the hostage crisis in Lima.
The Foreign Ministry in Bonn said Peruvian state minister Voto Bernalez had assured Kinkel that Peru would be guided by the desire to protect the lives of the hostages.
Germany's ambassador to Peru is among at least 200 hostages held by heavily-armed guerrillas of the Cuban-inspired Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement at the Japanese ambassador's residence.
Kinkel had appealed to Bernalez for prudence in Peru's efforts to free the hostages and requested that Peru refrain from any actions that could harm them.
"Bernalez told Kinkel that the actions of the Peruvian government will be led by the same premise," a Foreign Ministry spokesman said.
He told Kinkel that there were about 250 hostages being held by between 15 and 20 guerrillas. Bernalez also said Peru would consider Germany's offer to send a team of experts to help.
Earlier, Kinkel had told journalists: "We expect and assume that Peru will do everything in its powers so that the lives of the hostages are not endangered."
"I am extremely concerned and call on the hostage-takers to let the people free," he said.
German Ambassador Heribert Woeckel was being held with around 15 other hostages in one room of the residence, Kinkel said.
Kinkel ordered Germany's ambassador to Bolivia to go to Lima and take over the running of the German embassy. A crisis specialist from Bonn was also on the way to Lima, Kinkel said.
